WRITING.TEXT:
That's a fair criticism, though it's not the type of more illustration that demands a strong, clear light source and really suffers by having a more diffused, bounced, "everything is getting about the same amount of light" look. But, it also wouldn't be a bad thing if the light direction was more apparent and readable, that's something worth keeping in mind and striving for.
Ha, looking at it again for the reply, just so darn cute and entertaining. I've always loved dense drawings like this with lots of details you catching when you come back. This would be such a good style for a children's book or a "Where's Waldo"-type scan and find book.
Yeah, I could go for that. Adding matching consonant sounds helps smooth over the parts that don't rhyme perfectly.

I don't really think that's the definition, and certainly not the definition in the usual sense of the word rhyming. I think most people would expect a multisyllabic word to be rhymed with on all syllables, not just the last. or at least much closer on each syllable. I'm not a lyricist, so I don't know if slant rhyme is quite the right term to bring up, but the "pur-" part in purple needs to be approximated a lot more than it would be with multi-, princi-, or tri-. All of these vowel sounds are in complete opposition to the sound pur- makes.
Using your very loose criteria, you could also say that elevator rhymes with router or water prosecutor.
A few years?! It came out in 2015. :D

You should be very proud, I think it's wonderful! The illustration alone is great and charming as hell without any color, but the colors are so vibrant and well applied. The pipes feel round, I really like the shadows in the water. Everything feels like it's "in place", which is something I've struggled with while learning, giving things weight and form and having the appearance of resting on other elements.
Right, this was a Sun-Jin episode and you see news coverage of Hurley's lottery win in the background.

I just started paying Stardew a few weeks ago on PC and I'm incredibly excited to buy it again for Switch...helps that I got it in the big, super value ACLU humble bundle, but even if I'd bought it at full price, I'd still get it again to be able to play on the go or in bed. Though having the option to play in bed will probably make getting to sleep even more challenging.

We joke about it being silly to demand strong, progressing narrative in the show...but in this last season, I was aching for some more serious developments to occur. Instead you could interchange almost all of these episodes with any other at any point in the show's timeline. I thought this was a chance finally for them to disregard their own rules and some genuine changes could happen and add some finality to the show. I was excited when it looked like Alice might actually leave her job in "Bianca Toro"..but nah, status quo by the end. I wish they had been a little more interested in making the final season feel like a final season and had some fun with that freedom.
That is pretty ridiculous and unacceptable. I hope this show gets cancelled.

I love my G13 for painting. It's an absolute necessity for a drawing monitor for me. But I am curious about using a joy con. My monitor/desk setup isn't ideal and I do need to do a little stretching to get into the right position, where being wireless and tiny the joy con would be much more effortless and painless to integrate into the process. Might have to give it a spin tonight.
Sigh....I was in college. Just a freshman though, so that makes me feel a little less super old.

Very welcome, it was a quick, fun project. For these types of silhouette images, it's pretty simple. I use Photoshop, but it's something that could easily be done in a free program like [Gimp](https://www.gimp.org/) or [Inkscape](https://inkscape.org/en/). Open the original, low-res image in the program, resize to what you want your final image to be...or even bigger, doesn't hurt to go really big and then shrink down if needed when you're done...and then you trace over the low-res image on a new layer.
I like using the Pen tool in Photoshop as it creates a vector shape which can be continuously adjusted and stretched and resized without becoming pixelated or distorted. But if you aren't familiar with creating vector shapes, as long as you're working on a big canvas, you could just as easily use the regular ol' Brush tool and paint over low-res image. Either route, it's just a little patience and paying attention to details...in the end the image will turn out just as well.
So now you have the real world equivalent of a painted white silhouette on a transparency. Add another layer underneath of this to create the red background. And then another on top of the red and below the silhouette to create the blood splatter or whatever other texture you might want. I have a bunch of blood splatter and grunge brushes in Photoshop that kinda behave like stamps, so I can just pop down a bunch of splatter effects with dark red or black and then erase a bit or adjust the layer transparency until it looks how i want.
I don't know how familiar you are with creating graphics in general so this might be overkill or still vague, but it's a starting point. The gist is just to trace it in a graphics program on a separate layer after resizing it to a much larger canvas. You can look up tutorials on using the Pen tool or finding grungy brushes to get deeper into recreating it the exact way I did. Hope that helps some!

It's pretty dreadful. But if you're a longtime fan of Palahniuk and have grown accustomed to and tolerant of the last ~decade of "it sucks but I kinda can't look away" books, it's fascinating. It's pretty bonkers and absurd and takes Palahniuk-isms to an all new height.

I think you're right. I did it all pretty quick before bed and the low-res reference wasn't always entirely helpful for smaller details like that. Updated in my comment. It's subtle, but undoubtedly more polished looking.

[I had some free time this evening, so I made a super high res copy that should work on just about any size screen.](http://i.imgur.com/N3bOgfL.jpg)
Made it from scratch, so it's my own go at the blood splatters and it's not a pixel perfect recreation, but I hope that it's the overall spirit of the image that's most important! :D
Edit: [v2 with a bushier, Bobbier mustache.](http://i.imgur.com/3eyObOf.jpg)

If you're putting a lot of effort in the shoot, using a tripod and a lighting setup, it would be easy to shoot a "clean plate" first. Snap a picture of your empty "set" without any figures, the setup your figures without moving the camera or changing your lights. When you're editing you can put the clean plate on the base layer and your staged photos on a higher layer. Then you can literally erase the stands and anything else from your top layers and reveal the empty background on the layer below.
If you're careful about watching out for shadows and making sure the stands are positioned in the best places, the work should be very quick and easy.

My Donatello arrived today, Raph tomorrow. Man, you see all the photos and listen to all the rave reviews but nothing prepares you to witness with your own eyes. The sculpt and paint work is just phenomenal and hard to capture in a picture or video.

That's a very fair criticism. I worked downward and in trying to keep up a quick pace and not get stuck in a rut on one painting for more than a couple of days or get to the point where I fiddle with it until I ruin it, I rushed it through and called it done once I got the tomato and lettuce roughed in. I probably could have well spent another pass or two on the veggies and got some of the veins and hint of the tomato innards.
I may even go back and try to see how much I can add to it in that respect. I think there's the opportunity for a few more details on what's already dried, even with my cheap, stubborn paper.
It's been scanned so it can live in all our hearts forever, it may as well live in your stomach for a li'l while.
Thanks you. I was worried it might have veered into too saturated/cartoony territory.

Hopefully that all made sense. It's like you're making a pebbled, abstract texture that works well with watercolor...interesting, organic-looking, diffused shapes that sometimes blend gradually with their neighbors and sometimes keep harder edges. And that pattern just happens to look a whole lot like a hamburger patty.
This is on 4x6" paper, the burger by itself is about 4" tall.

Thanks very much!
The patty is one of those things I find pretty easy to make taking advantage of watercolor's natural characteristics. It's a lighter brown wash first and then lots of dabbing with dark brown and black. Sometimes wet on wet, but at least always with a very wet brush so the paint spots had lots of water to disperse in and help create the texture. Continue this with more and more black in the right places to help create the look of contours and shadows. It's probably like...five or six passes of adding texture like this, drying in between. After I'm pretty happy with the texture and it looks like it has form, I'll do a couple really light washes of orange or red to "revive" it a bit, all the speckling(at least how I do it) usually makes it a little dull and gray. Finally, the lighter spots on the left side of the burger or highlights made with a gel pen and then painted over lightly with brown to kill the white some and blend the gel where I don't want a bright, tight edged dot.
For the bun, I actually just painted around the highlights. I'm using really cheap paper and it doesn't blot or scrub very well at all so it was safer to do this. They're big enough and soft edged enough that it wasn't too much of a challenge to do it like this. Painted yellow/brown wash down first. Blended the highlights a little with just a wet brush. Added a really wet, darker brown wash on the right and blend it out towards the left. Worked on adding the texture along the bottom of the bun with some lighter brown. Once I was pretty happy with the shading, I added a couple of light washes of bright yellow, like the same pigment used for the cheese, over the whole bun-highlights and all-to make it look hot and buttery.
It probably **would** be a lot easier and smoother looking to do the being mostly in one go with wet on wet and pick up the highlights with paper towel. I've decided to paint a burger a month as a kinda benchmark for myself...I'll have to try that method on next month's.
Oh cool! Great, thank you.

This is so great, such a whimsical, creepy style. All your efforts seem so confident and well executed, you have great control over the paint. Do you have an Instagram or blog or anywhere like that I could follow you on?

WRITING.TITLE: Bacon cheeseburger, trying to balance adding detail and overworking

WRITING.TEXT:
This might just be us talking, buried in a week old thread..but just for courtesy sake...
[Overall, I thought the ending...](#s "covered what it needed to, just with more mundane, less flashy/sinister/supernatural machinations. Lisa's grief turned into a kind of mental illness and that can kinda, maybe in a "too convenient" way, brush away some plot holes and weirdness. My biggest pet peeve was how the people who visited her became near instant converts and started acting differently. Because they seemed to act so suddenly odd only for the sake of the novel's mystery, when really nothing happened to them and they didn't have a reason to be so strange around friends or coworkers. They had no reason not to explain everything.")
Confirmed!
Traded Mini Metro for /u/Stonga 's Punch Club.

I just read both books in the last week and that might be for the best. I liked both books, but they certainly are a bit different than a lot of fiction, they're more like accounts of real, obscure stories in that they meander and frustrate and don't tie things up neatly like you often expect fiction to. Real life is mysterious and unknowable and unsatisfying enough, you kinda want a made-up story to provide you with some closure.
Wolf in White Van is definitely even more ultimately about the characters and not the plot. There were multiple threads that opened up that I thought the story was going to go down only for it to really go down none at all. So if Harvester frustrated you with that lack of a strong, traditional plot to travel down...Wolf will almost certainly make you pull your hair out.
Yes sir!
I don't know if his strategy of "having infinite guns=upper hand" is completely solid.
Would Mini Metro for Punch Club work?

A couple weeks ago, I made a [shadow box paper cutout project like this](https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/originals/38/23/f1/3823f13761932f411eb4692da01e1378.jpg) and I looked into the paper cutters afterwards thinking about how easier it would've been and how much more detailed the images could've been if I didn't have to do it by hand.
I also like to make boardgame inserts out of 2mm presentation board and wondered if these might be able to help with that as well. I really enjoy designing the inserts but the execution can get tedious and sometimes frustrating. Again, not being limited to what I can do by hand would really open up a lot of possibilities for useful inserts. But in my bit of research, I think 2mm might be pushing the limits of any consumer machine in this tier.

And it hits a perfect tone of a little more serious during the name transition but still staying funny. I'm personally not a huge rap fan and love the mix of music and comedy Tyler crafted, so I'm a bit biased. I wouldn't be terribly interested in a serious effort, but if he wanted to he certainly has the chops.

Zero shade intended. I'm very impressed by the collection and the display, I wish there was an album so we could see close-ups and identify exactly who all is in there.

I think the point is, it's something these companies that have done a hundred projects should need to expect...and yet still don't. It's mind-boggling.
And for your second point, they absolutely do not need to rely on Kickstarter. Some boardgame companies, and many others I'm sure, have helped created this perception where we should believe that no product can ever be created they were for decades and decades...you know, where a company used investors and in-house money and had to take risks to produce items and hope to eventually turn a profit. Nowadays, why ever bother doing this when you have thousands of people storming your gates to give you a million dollars in interest-free loans, like it was a privilege to do so.
Don't get me wrong, I still Kickstart games, but it has to be a more special package from a smaller company or individual better fits the spirit of Kickstarter. These million dollar projects that fund in an hour from companies taking advantage of the system just seem gross to me.

My watercolor lessons are usually YouTube videos, and one of my favorite channels is Steve Mitchell's Mind of Watercolor. He has spent a few videos painting various birds in one of his journals and I really liked that idea of creating a themed journal. But before I steal that idea and potentially ruin a $20+ book, I'm practicing on single pages in my $2 Hobby Lobby books.
I'm still trying to find a balance between the pen work and the watercolor. I'm more confident drawing so right now I'm usually happier with these "coloring book" type approaches, but I don't want to be so that if you could lift away the ink lines you would just see dull, flat patches of color. I don't want the ink to do all the detail and value work. I like this level of pen detail fairly well, not a whole lot of hatching serving as a substitute for watercolor shading.

Indeed. I like the real animals from the Christmas event-polar bear, walrus, etc, so you not really have anything like that this time around is really disappointing. All the goofy, phony fish get put into storage immediately, but the red jellyfish is neat and worth stocking up on.

It's pretty fun once you get through the pain and you can almost predict what the watercolor might want to do half the time!

This is incredible. As someone at any level, it's stunning...but especially as a beginner, it's mind-boggling to look at this and try to imagine the work process to get such great results. The level of detail and vividness is wonderful, but it's not too sterile or overworked and still has the texture and tell-tale watercolor qualities you wouldn't want to obscure entirely.
